Description: SUMMARY:  On February 7, 2018, Harlan L. Kelly, Jr., General Manager of the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, City and County of San Francisco, sent a letter to Cmmrs. Picker and Randolph. The letter concerned a revised Draft Resolution E-4907. The letter identified procedural, legal, and factual concerns with the Resolution. Further, Mr. Kelly requested that the Commission not adopt the Resolution in light of the stated deficiencies. A copy of the letter is attached to the notice.

Guzman Aceves, Peterman, Randolph, and Rechtschaffen, and to Edward Randolph, Director of the Energy Division. The letter raises objections to revised Draft Resolution E-4907. A copy of the letter is attached to the notice.

On November 22, 2005, Billy Blattner, CPUC Relations Manager, San Diego Gas and Electric Company (SDG&E), met with Rami Kahlon, advisor to Cmmr. Peevey, in San Francisco. Blattner stated that SDG&E supports Community Choice Aggregation (CCA), but is concerned that language in the Proposed Decision (PD) creates constitutional issues. Specifically, Blattner suggested that PD use the `billing process' language of AB 117. Blattner noted that this should be a mutually beneficial outcome for utilities and community choice aggregators. Blattner also suggested that the marketing prohibition be clarified so that ordinary utility-customer communications that are unrelated to CCA activities are not captured.

LATE FILED.  On November 9, 2005, David Orth, General Manager of Kings River Conservation District (KRCD), met with Rami Kahlon, advisor to Cmmr. Peevey, in San Francisco. Also present was John Dalessi, Associate Director at Navigant Consulting, Inc. Orth explained that KRCD is seeking to improve reliability in and around its service area by building new electric generation facilities. Orth explained that KRCD has executed a memorandum of understanding with twelve local governments to develop a regional Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) program that would be supplied in large part by new generation owned by KRCD. Orth expressed general support for the proposed decision (PD) of ALJ Malcolm. Dalessi expressed concern with one aspect of the PD that would leave the CCA with little recourse in the event of nonpayment by customers.

LATE FILED.  On November 3, 2005, David Orth, General Manager of Kings River Conservation District (KRCD), met with Stephen St. Marie, advisor to Cmmr. Bohn, in San Francisco. Also present was John Dalessi, Associate Director at Navigant Consulting, Inc. Orth explained that KRCD is seeking to improve reliability in and around its service area by building new electric generation facilities. Orth explained that KRCD has executed a memorandum of understanding with twelve local governments to develop a regional CCA program that would be supplied in large part by new generation owned by KRCD. Orth expressed general support for the proposed decision (PD) of ALJ Malcolm and expressed concern with one aspect of the PD that would leave the CCA with little recourse in the event of nonpayment by customers.

On October 19, 2005, Sidney Dietz, Manager, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Cmmr. Brown in San Francisco. Also present were David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Brown, and Sandra Burns, Manager, Gas and Electric Supply, and Calvin Yee, Manager, Account Services, for PG&E. Dietz expressed PG&E's historical and continued support of Community Choice Aggregation (CCA) and its interest in a fair tariff and continued CPUC oversight of the CCAs. Dietz explained the proposal to ensure the orderly transfer of Resource Adequacy responsibilities for CCA loads.

On October 12, 2005, Sidney Dietz, Manager, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Stephen St. Marie, advisor to Cmmr. Bohn, in San Francisco. Also present were Robert Lane, advisor to Cmmr. Bohn, and Paul Holton, Manager, Energy Revenue Requirements, Sandra Burns, Manager, Gas and Electric Supply, and Calvin Yee, Manager, Account Services, for PG&E. Dietz expressed PG&E's historical and continued support of Community Choice Aggregation (CCA). Holton expressed PG&E's interest in a fair tariff and continued Commission oversight of the CCAs. Yee explained the important sections of PG&E's proposed tariff. Burns explained PG&E's proposal to ensure the orderly transfer of Resource Adequacy responsibilities for CCA loads.

LATE FILED.  On October 3, 2005, Michael Meacham, Director of Conservation and Environmental Services, City of Chula Vista, representing the Local Government Commission Coalition (LGCC), met with Brian Prusnek, advisor to Cmmr. Kennedy, in San Francisco. Also present were Sean Casey, Manager of Regulatory Affairs, San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, Gwen Johnson, Solar Projects Coordinator for the County of Marin, and Jody London, expert witness for LGCC. LGCC representatives described the composition of the LGCC. Meacham provided an overview of the City of Chula Vista's involvement in energy issues, and the process by which Chula Vista is conducting its ongoing study of community choice aggregation (CCA). Casey described the City and County of San Francisco's ongoing efforts to develop a draft Implementation Plan for CCA. Johnson discussed the motivations for the County of Marin's study of CCA and the process by which it is conducting the study. London provided an update on the City of Pleasanton's CCA.

On April 28, Eric Eisenman, Chief, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Aaron Johnson, advisor to Cmmr. Grueneich, in San Francisco. Also present were Larry Chaset, advisor to Cmmr. Grueneich, Brian Prusnek, advisor to Cmmr. Kennedy, and Dennis Keane, Manager, Service Analysis, for PG&E. Written material (attached to the notice) was used. Eisenman explained that the goal of PG&E and other utilities in Phase 2 of the proceeding is that no costs be shifted to bundled customers, that Resource Adequacy not be compromised, and that the Commission continue to have jurisdiction over Community Choice Aggregations (CCAs). Eisenman advocated that PG&E should not be relieved of its Resource Adequacy responsibilities until a CCA commits to a firm date for supplying energy to its customers.

Decision D0412046 - Resolves Phase 1 issues on pricing and costs attributable to community choice aggregators and related matters.

On December 8, 2004, Eric Eisenman, Chief, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Brown, Sandra Burns, Manager, Gas & Electric Supply, and Paul Holton, Manager, Revenue Requirements, for PG&E, and Lad Lorenz, William Blattner, and Wayne Sakarias, for San Diego Gas and Electric Company.  Eisenman explained that PG&E supports the implementation of Community Choice Aggregation (CCA).  Burns expressed concerns about the proposed decision's (PD) discussion on the opportunity for CCA to take delivery of a portion of a Department of Water Resources (DWR) contract. Burns added that the cost responsibility surcharge (CRS) is a reflection of the above market component of PG&E's costs, and does not entitle the CCA to delivery of power. Burns also requested that the final order clarify that the $.022/kWh CRS includes only the DWR power charge and CTC. Holton explained that the PD's granting a CRS exemption for the Norton Air Force Base is a poor policy inconsistent with AB 117, and will lead to numerous other requests for exemptions.

On December 8, 2004, Lad Lorenz, Vice President - Regulatory Affairs, San Diego Gas and Electric Company (SDG&E), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Brown, and Julie Fitch, advisor to Pres. Peevey, in two separate meetings in San Francisco. Also present were Wayne Sakarias, Director of Legislative Analysis, and Billy Blattner, CPUC Relations Manager, for SDG&E. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used. Blattner stated that SDG&E supported AB 117 and supports Community Choice Aggregation (CCA), but it must not conflict with utility resource planning and bundled ratepayers must be protected. Sakarias explained that the proposed decision (PD) conflicts with approved procurement and resource adequacy decisions as well as state law. Sakarias also explained that cost responsibility surcharge (CRS) represents the above-market cost of Department of Water Resources (DWR) power, not the cost of the physical power or capacity. Sakarias stated that determination in the PD that CCAs are entitled to `in-kind' allocation of DWR contracts would result in bundled customers subsidizing free or reduced-cost power to CCA customers. Sakarias expressed concerns about the PD's treatment of confidentiality, phasing in CCA and certain transaction costs, and recommended hat the PD clarify that the CRS does not include the bond charge.

On November 29, 2004, Eric Eisenman, Chief, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Julie Fitch, advisor to Cmmr. Peevey, in San Francisco. Also present were David Rubin, Director, Service Analysis, Sandra Burns, Manager, Gas & Electric Supply, and Paul Holton, Manager, Revenue Requirements, for PG&E. Eisenman explained that PG&E supports the implementation of Community Choice Aggregation (CCA).  Burns expressed concerns about the proposed decision's (PD) discussion on the opportunity for CCA to take delivery of a portion of a Department of Water Resources (DWR) contract. Burns added that the cost responsibility surcharge (CRS) is a reflection of the above market component of PG&E's costs, and does not entitle the CCA to delivery of power. Burns also requested that the final order clarify that the $.022/kWh CRS includes only the DWR power charge and CTC. Rubin explained that the PD's granting a CRS exemption for the Norton Air Force Base is a poor policy inconsistent with AB 117, and will lead to numerous other requests for exemptions.

On September 13, 2004, Dierdre Bennett, City Mayor of the City of Colton (City), met with Cmmr. Wood in Colton.  Also present were Steven Weissman, advisor to Cmmr. Wood, and Daryl Parrish, the City Manager, and Jennette Olko, the City Electric Utility General Manager, for the City.  Mayor Bennett discussed Senate Bill 1575, which concerned an exemption from certain cost responsibility surcharges for a joint powers authority providing electricity to a closed military base.  However, since SB 1575 has failed passage, Bennett expressed concern about the economics of providing electrical service to Norton Air Force Base through the Inland Valley Development Agency.

THIS IS AN AUGMENTED NOTICE OF AN EX PARTE COMMUNICATION THAT WAS FILED ON AUGUST 26, 2004, AND APPEARED IN THE CALENDAR OF SEPTEMBER 9, 2004.  On August 23, 2004, Mike Preston, Vice Mayor of the City of San Marcos (City), met with Cmmr. Wood in San Diego. Also present were Steve Weissman, advisor to Cmmr. Wood, and Rick Gittings, the City Manager.  Vice Mayor Preston discussed the impacts associated with Community Choice Aggregation relating to not only the exit fee issue, as well as to direct access issues, but also the concept of investor owned utilities (IOUs) adding an additional "exit fee" in order to fully plan their resource allocation mix in the future if communities began buying energy for customers within their community, which are also customers of the IOU. The City representatives also discussed a Joint Powers Agreement between the City of Victorville and the City of San Marcos and explained how that might assist in generating new energy within the State of California, particularly energy that may be found and declared to be "renewable resources/green energy."  The City representatives also noted the importance of the process and establishing the rules for AB 117 Community Choice Aggregation.  The City representatives indicated their position as being in favor of Community Choice Aggregation.

LATE FILED. On August 23, 2004, Mike Preston, Vice Mayor of the City of San Marcos (City), met with Cmmr. Wood in San Diego. Also present were Steven Weissman, advisor to Cmmr. The City representatives also discussed a Joint Powers Agreement between the City of Victorville and the City of San Marcos and explained how that might assist in generating new energy within the State of California, particularly energy that may be found and declared to be "renewable resources/green energy." The City representatives discussed community choice aggregation, California Clean Energy Resources Authority, and $1 billion energy cost shift to San Diego Gas & Electric Company ratepayers, or "Opinion Implementing a Permanent Allocation of the Annual Revenue Requirement Determination of the California Department of Water Resources."

On May 11, 2004, Eric Eisenman, Chief, Regulatory Relations, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Julie Fitch, advisor to Cmmr. Peevey, in San Francisco.  Also present were Cheryl Cox, advisor to Cmmr. Lynch, Amy Chan of the Energy Division, and David Rubin, Director, Service Analysis, Sandra Burns, Manager, Gas & Electric Supply, Del Evans, Manager, Account Services, and Paul Holton, Manager, Revenue Requirements, for PG&E.  Written material (attached to the notice) was used.  Rubin stated that PG&E is committed to working with potential CCAs and the Commission to fairly implement CCA service.  Burns explained that a customer responsibility surcharge (CRS) needs to be developed so that remaining bundled customers are indifferent to CCA service.  Burns stated that the CRS should reflect all above-market procurement-related costs.  Burns stated that PG&E recommends that CCAs should have a five-year resource adequacy requirement and that a single CRS rate be applicable for all CCA participants and all usage up to 130% of baseline.  Evans outlined PG&E's recommendations on implementation cost recovery and transaction cost recovery.
